title: How to Turn on Your Car Heater in 3 Easy Steps

steps.title: Turn on your car’s engine.
steps.content: Turn on your car’s engine. Whether you have a key ignition or a push-button ignition, turn your car’s engine on. The engine is responsible for generating the heat that gets pushed through your vents when you turn the heater on. [1] X Research source It typically takes around 5 minutes for your car’s engine to heat up, so you can either start driving or let your car idle for a few minutes.

steps.title: Turn the temperature dial to adjust the heat level.
steps.content: Turn the temperature dial to adjust the heat level. The temperature dial is usually located in the center console and has blue and red coloring. Blue indicates cold air, while red indicates hot, so adjust your dial toward the red (usually to the right). The further you turn or push the dial to the right, the higher the heat level will be. [2] X Research source If you have a digital display, simply click on the temperature control icon and press the + button on the screen to amp up the heat.

steps.title: Adjust the fan control to your preferred fan speed.
steps.content: Adjust the fan control to your preferred fan speed. Locate the fan speed control (usually directly next to or beneath the temperature control), and turn or push the dial to the right until you’ve found a comfortable speed. The higher the fan speed control, the faster your car will heat up. [3] X Research source You can also adjust the airflow dial (usually right next to the fan speed control) to direct the heat to specific areas: Windshield and rear windshield vents (to defrost a foggy windshield ) Dashboard Windshield and face vents Face and feet vents

steps.title: The recirculation button circulates air from inside your car’s cabin.
steps.content: The recirculation button circulates air from inside your car’s cabin. The car heater pulls air from outside the cabin through the heat exchanger and distributes it to the inside to warm up the interior. If you're extra chilly when you hop in your car, try pushing the recirculation button (usually near the airflow controls). That way, your car will use the air inside your vehicle, which is likely warmer than the air outside, and it will take a little less time to heat up. You can also use the recirculation button when the air quality outside your vehicle is poor and you don’t want it circulating through your cabin. Don’t use the recirculation button if you’re trying to defrost a misty windshield. The air from inside the car’s cabin typically holds moisture and will fog up the windshield even more. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Check if your heater vents are closed.
steps.content: Check if your heater vents are closed. It’s easy to accidentally close or lower one or more heating vents throughout your car. If your heater’s on and adjusted to your preferred settings, but you can’t feel any air circulating, check your vents to ensure they aren’t closed. Open your heater vents by simply rolling or pushing the dial from one side to the other, up to down, and vice versa, until you can feel the air blowing out again.

steps.title: Check your car’s coolant level.
steps.content: Check your car’s coolant level. Check your coolant level to make sure it’s not low. If your coolant level is low, the hot fluid won’t reach your heater’s core and leave you without hot air to heat up your chilly hands and feet! [5] X Research source Always ensure the engine is cool before checking the coolant. Otherwise, you will burn yourself.

steps.title: Have your thermostat inspected.
steps.content: Have your thermostat inspected. If you’re still having trouble with your heater after turning your car on, adjusting the temperature, and checking the fan settings, you might have a faulty thermostat. When your thermostat gets stuck, either open or closed, it can stop your car’s heater from functioning or inhibit your engine from cooling properly. [6] X Research source Make an appointment to have your car inspected to find the root of the problem and ensure that your heater issue is solved correctly.
